verses.verse: Don't <S%H1984><s%> boast about tomorrow; <S%H4279><s%> for you don't <S%H3045><s%> know what a day <S%H4279><s%> may bring forth. <S%H3205><s%>
Let another man <S%H2114><s%> praise <S%H1984><s%> you, <S%H6310><s%> and not your own mouth; a stranger, <S%H5237><s%> and not your own lips. <S%H8193><s%>
A stone <S%H68><s%> is heavy, <S%H3514><s%> and sand <S%H2344><s%> is a burden; <S%H5192><s%> but a fool <S%H191><s%>'s provocation <S%H3708><s%> is heavier <S%H3515><s%> than both. <S%H8147><s%>
Wrath <S%H2534><s%> is cruel, <S%H395><s%> and anger <S%H639><s%> is overwhelming; <S%H7858><s%> but who is able to stand <S%H5975><s%> before <S%H6440><s%> jealousy? <S%H7068><s%>
Better <S%H2896><s%> is open <S%H1540><s%> rebuke <S%H8433><s%> than hidden <S%H5641><s%> love. <S%H160><s%>
Faithful <S%H539><s%> are the wounds <S%H6482><s%> of a friend; <S%H157><s%> although the kisses <S%H5390><s%> of an enemy <S%H8130><s%> are profuse. <S%H6280><s%>
A full <S%H7649><s%> soul <S%H5315><s%> loathes <S%H947><s%> a honeycomb; <S%H5317><s%> but to a hungry <S%H7457><s%> soul, <S%H5315><s%> every bitter thing <S%H4751><s%> is sweet. <S%H4966><s%>
As a bird <S%H6833><s%> that wanders <S%H5074><s%> from her nest, <S%H7064><s%> so is a man <S%H376><s%> who wanders <S%H5074><s%> from his home. <S%H4725><s%>

Perfume <S%H7004><s%> and incense <S%H8081><s%> bring joy <S%H8055><s%> to the heart; <S%H3820><s%> so <S%H4986><s%> does earnest <S%H5315><s%> counsel <S%H6098><s%> from a man <S%H7453><s%>'s friend.

Don't <S%H5800><s%> forsake your friend <S%H7453><s%> and your father <S%H1><s%>'s friend. <S%H7453><s%> Don't <S%H935><s%> go to your brother <S%H251><s%>'s house <S%H1004><s%> in the day <S%H3117><s%> of your disaster: <S%H343><s%> better <S%H2896><s%> is a neighbor <S%H7934><s%> who is near <S%H7138><s%> than a distant <S%H7350><s%> brother. <S%H251><s%>
Be wise, <S%H2449><s%> my son, <S%H1121><s%> and bring joy <S%H8055><s%> to my heart, <S%H3820><s%> then I can answer <S%H7725><s%> my tormentor. <S%H2778><s%>
A prudent <S%H6175><s%> man sees <S%H7200><s%> danger <S%H7451><s%> and takes refuge; <S%H5641><s%> but the simple <S%H6612><s%> pass on, <S%H5674><s%> and suffer for it. <S%H6064><s%>
Take <S%H3947><s%> his garment <S%H899><s%> when he puts up collateral <S%H6148><s%> for a stranger. <S%H2114><s%> Hold <S%H2254><s%> it for a wayward woman! <S%H5237><s%>

He who blesses <S%H1288><s%> his neighbor <S%H7453><s%> with a loud <S%H1419><s%> voice <S%H6963><s%> early <S%H7925><s%> in the morning, <S%H7925><s%> it will be taken <S%H2803><s%> as a curse by him. <S%H7045><s%>
A continual <S%H2956><s%> dropping <S%H1812><s%> on a rainy <S%H5464><s%> day <S%H3117><s%> and a contentious <S%H4079><s%> wife <S%H802><s%> are alike: <S%H7737><s%>
restraining <S%H6845><s%> her is like restraining <S%H6845><s%> the wind, <S%H7307><s%> or like grasping <S%H7121><s%> oil <S%H8081><s%> in his right hand. <S%H3225><s%>
Iron <S%H1270><s%> sharpens <S%H2300><s%> iron; <S%H1270><s%> so a man <S%H376><s%> sharpens <S%H2300><s%> his friend <S%H7453><s%>'s countenance. <S%H6440><s%>
Whoever tends <S%H5341><s%> the fig tree <S%H8384><s%> shall eat <S%H398><s%> its fruit. <S%H6529><s%> He who looks <S%H8104><s%> after his master <S%H113><s%> shall be honored. <S%H3513><s%>
As water <S%H4325><s%> reflects a face, <S%H6440><s%> so a man <S%H120><s%>'s heart <S%H3820><s%> reflects <S%H120><s%> the man. <S%H120><s%>
Sheol <S%H7585><s%> and Abaddon <S%H11><s%> are never <S%H3808><s%> satisfied; <S%H7646><s%> and a man <S%H120><s%>'s eyes <S%H5869><s%> are never satisfied. <S%H7646><s%>
The crucible <S%H4715><s%> is for silver, <S%H3701><s%> and the furnace <S%H3564><s%> for gold; <S%H2091><s%> but man <S%H376><s%> is refined <S%H6310><s%> by his praise. <S%H4110><s%>

Though you grind <S%H3806><s%> a fool <S%H191><s%> in a mortar <S%H4388><s%> with <S%H8432><s%> a pestle <S%H5940><s%> along with grain, <S%H7383><s%> yet his foolishness <S%H200><s%> will not be removed from him. <S%H5493><s%>
Know <S%H3045><s%> well <S%H3045><s%> the state <S%H6440><s%> of your flocks, <S%H6629><s%> and pay <S%H3820><s%> attention <S%H7896><s%> to your herds: <S%H5739><s%>
for riches <S%H2633><s%> are not forever, <S%H5769><s%> nor does even the crown <S%H5145><s%> endure to all <S%H1755><s%> generations. <S%H1755><s%>
The hay <S%H2682><s%> is removed, <S%H2682><s%> and the new growth <S%H1877><s%> appears, <S%H7200><s%> the grasses <S%H6212><s%> of the hills <S%H2022><s%> are gathered in. <S%H622><s%>
The lambs <S%H3532><s%> are for your clothing, <S%H3830><s%> and the goats <S%H6260><s%> are the price <S%H4242><s%> of a field. <S%H7704><s%>

There will be plenty <S%H1767><s%> of goats <S%H5795><s%>' milk <S%H2461><s%> for your food, <S%H3899><s%> for your family <S%H1004><s%>'s food, <S%H3899><s%> and for the nourishment <S%H2416><s%> of your servant girls. <S%H5291><s%>
